body:
@KevinYang21 hi, how do you guys get >30k running tasks in Airbnb internal cluster?
We can only get 20 or so running tasks in our internal cluster, because the 16-vCores PostgreSQL server our airflow is using keeps at 90% CPU consumption all the time, and we don't know how to make this down a little bit. 
So curious!
Thanks in advance!
The build is green :). I amended the commit to refer AIRFLOW-4545 and pushed it to v1-10-test branch so that it gets included in 1.10.4.
@tssujt did you have time to work on this?

@Jerevia
Why did you open the PR against `1.10 branch` and not against `Master`?

@sherifkk 
There seem to be a problem with checking the docs:
```
[2019-05-03 04:41:06,791] {__init__.py:51} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor
None:3: (ERROR/3) Unexpected indentation.
None:9: (WARNING/2) Definition list ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.
None:10: (WARNING/2) Block quote ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.
```

Also you need to address @bryanyang0528 comment and add tests.
@CloudChaoszero Did you have time to fix ?
@eepstein CI is green. Tests passed. Just wait for committers to review.
I found it was fixed in #5178

@tssujt This probably will need a fix to the old UI as well as https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/5178 only fix it in the RABC UI. Maybe you can convert this PR to target the v10 test branch? Better ask @kaxil  what he thinks.

Hi @kaxil - I added some js and config for this. The intended behavior is:

- The new config will default to True
- If True, DAG code and TI log views will default to wrapping. If False, they will default to existing behavior.
- There is clickable text on each view that will toggle wrapping; this is not persisted.

I don't have a working local dev instance right now however, so I am hoping someone else can take a look at this.

@OmerJog All test passing now, and I learned some python unit testing in the process :-) I still need to add the test requested by @fenglu-g.

@DanSedov I'm afraid I may have done some violence to your (excellent!) patch to move the dataproc operator away from monitoring the cluster to monitoring the operation.  I believe my change looks at the cluster no more than necessary, but would appreciate your thoughts if you have a moment to look.  Thanks!

Good news @OmerJog , I added a test that work @fenglu-g.  The bad news is that it uses a pattern that @DanSedov retired in his PR, namely inspecting the log messages.  I wasn't able to find another to verify that a cluster delete was attempted because my `_execute_delete` method in the hook is a `@staticmethod`.   Per my earlier comment, I may have undone some of Dan's work with this patch, so I'll revisit the test if there's a better way.
@fmao please rebase onto master
